If your company's annual turnover is below the GST registration threshold of INR 40 lakhs, your company is not required to register for GST or charge GST on its taxable supplies. However, you may still be required to pay GST on your business inputs (e.g., the goods and services you purchase for your business). You may be able to claim GST credits for the taxes paid on your business inputs if you are registered for GST.

As a partner in the business, you will also be required to pay income tax on your share of the profits at the applicable tax rates. You will need to file an income tax return each year to report your income and pay any taxes due.

As a resident individual in India, the income tax rate for the financial year 2021-2022 is as follows:

* Up to INR 2.5 lakhs: Nil
* INR 2.5 lakhs to INR 5 lakhs: 5%
* INR 5 lakhs to INR 7.5 lakhs: 10%
* INR 7.5 lakhs to INR 10 lakhs: 15%
* INR 10 lakhs to INR 12.5 lakhs: 20%
* INR 12.5 lakhs to INR 15 lakhs: 25%
* Above INR 15 lakhs: 30%

Therefore, if your share of the profits is up to INR 5 lakhs, you would not be required to pay any income tax. If your share of the profits is above INR 5 lakhs, you would be required to pay income tax at the applicable tax rate.

The old tax regime refers to the tax system that was in place in India prior to the implementation of the new tax regime in the financial year 2020-2021. Under the old tax regime, individuals had the option to pay tax at the applicable tax rates or claim deductions and exemptions to reduce their tax liability.

The new tax regime, on the other hand, does not offer deductions and exemptions, but instead provides a lower tax rate for individuals who forego these deductions and exemptions. The new tax regime also introduces a higher tax rate for individuals with a higher income.

As a resident individual in India, you have the option to choose between the old tax regime and the new tax regime each financial year. You can choose the tax regime that provides the lower tax liability based on your individual circumstances. It is a good idea to consult with a tax professional to determine which tax regime is more beneficial for you.
